articles.headline: Some Colleges Will Soon Charge $100,000 a Year. How Did This Happen?
articles.snippet: Some Vanderbilt students will have $100,000 in total expenses for the 2024-25 school year. The school doesn’t really want to talk about it.
articles.abstract: Some Vanderbilt students will have $100,000 in total expenses for the 2024-25 school year. The school doesn’t really want to talk about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was only a matter of time before a college would have the nerve to quote its cost of attendance at nearly $100,000 a year. This spring, we’re catching our first glimpse of it.

articles.headline: Some of Trump’s Biggest Political Backers Also Threw Trump Media a Lifeline
articles.snippet: Two billionaires, a wealthy election denier and a mysterious Russia-linked trust invested in the Trump company long before it went public.
articles.abstract: Two billionaires, a wealthy election denier and a mysterious Russia-linked trust invested in the Trump company long before it went public.
articles.lead_paragraph: Marty Davis, the wealthy Minnesota head of a kitchen countertop manufacturing company, is a steadfast supporter of former President Donald J. Trump. He contributed hundreds of thousands of dollars to help elect Mr. Trump in 2020, and encouraged him to fight to overturn the 2020 election results.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: Earthquake Rattles New York and New Jersey, but Does Little Damage
articles.snippet: An earthquake struck the Northeast on Friday, rippling from Philadelphia to Boston.
articles.abstract: An earthquake struck the Northeast on Friday, rippling from Philadelphia to Boston.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a general store in New Jersey, near the epicenter of the earthquake, the sound was so loud that the staff thought a truck had crashed into the building.

articles.headline: In Threatening Israel, Biden Hopes to Avoid a Rupture
articles.snippet: The president has put Israel’s leader “on probation,” as a veteran diplomat put it. The threat is not idle, aides said, but he wants to force a course correction rather than follow through.
articles.abstract: The president has put Israel’s leader “on probation,” as a veteran diplomat put it. The threat is not idle, aides said, but he wants to force a course correction rather than follow through.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the time President Biden hung up the phone, he had finally delivered the threat he had refused to make for months: Israel had to change course, he told Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, or the United States would.

articles.headline: How Tech Giants Cut Corners to Harvest Data for A.I.
articles.snippet: OpenAI, Google and Meta ignored corporate policies, altered their own rules and discussed skirting copyright law as they sought online information to train their newest artificial intelligence systems.
articles.abstract: OpenAI, Google and Meta ignored corporate policies, altered their own rules and discussed skirting copyright law as they sought online information to train their newest artificial intelligence systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: In late 2021, OpenAI faced a supply problem.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz, Cecilia Kang, Sheera Frenkel, Stuart A. Thompson and Nico Grant

articles.headline: Pardoned for Serving in Ukraine, They Return to Russia to Kill Again
articles.snippet: Recruiting convicts for its army has given Russia a manpower advantage. But it is backfiring in tragic ways when former inmates are pardoned and return home to commit new crimes.
articles.abstract: Recruiting convicts for its army has given Russia a manpower advantage. But it is backfiring in tragic ways when former inmates are pardoned and return home to commit new crimes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Viktor Savvinov had already been imprisoned several times for various crimes — including robbery, auto theft and assault — when he murdered a female drinking companion during a quarrel in 2020, stabbing her in the chest with four knives.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Milana Mazaeva

articles.headline: Consumers Hate ‘Price Discrimination,’ but They Sure Love a Discount
articles.snippet: The Wendy’s debacle is a warning shot for brands: If you want to play with prices, make sure to communicate why and whom it could help.
articles.abstract: The Wendy’s debacle is a warning shot for brands: If you want to play with prices, make sure to communicate why and whom it could help.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s been a strange and maddening couple of years for consumers, with prices of essential goods soaring and then sinking, turning household budgets upside down.

articles.headline: In Battle Over Health Care Costs, Private Equity Plays Both Sides
articles.snippet: As medical practices owned by private equity firms fuel overbilling, a payment tool also backed by such investors helps insurers boost their profits.
articles.abstract: As medical practices owned by private equity firms fuel overbilling, a payment tool also backed by such investors helps insurers boost their profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Insurance companies have long blamed private-equity-owned hospitals and physician groups for exorbitant billing that drives up health care costs. But a tool backed by private equity is helping insurers make billions of dollars and shift costs to patients.

articles.headline: Insurers Reap Hidden Fees by Slashing Payments. You May Get the Bill.
articles.snippet: A little-known data firm helps health insurers make more when less of an out-of-network claim gets paid. Patients can be on the hook for the difference.
articles.abstract: A little-known data firm helps health insurers make more when less of an out-of-network claim gets paid. Patients can be on the hook for the difference.
articles.lead_paragraph: Weeks after undergoing heart surgery, Gail Lawson found herself back in an operating room. Her incision wasn’t healing, and an infection was spreading.

articles.headline: Gazing Skyward, and Awaiting a Moment of Awe
articles.snippet: Millions of people making plans to be in the path of the solar eclipse on Monday know it will be awe-inspiring. What is that feeling?
articles.abstract: Millions of people making plans to be in the path of the solar eclipse on Monday know it will be awe-inspiring. What is that feeling?
articles.lead_paragraph: The moment she saw the sun, something inside Julie McKelvey changed.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias and Stella Blackmon

articles.headline: How Gaza Protesters Are Challenging Democratic Leaders
articles.snippet: From President Biden to the mayors of small cities, Democrats have been trailed by demonstrators who are complicating the party’s ability to campaign in an election year.
articles.abstract: From President Biden to the mayors of small cities, Democrats have been trailed by demonstrators who are complicating the party’s ability to campaign in an election year.
articles.lead_paragraph: In Detroit, a congressman’s holiday party devolved into chaos and a broken nose after demonstrators protesting the war in Gaza appeared with bullhorns.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer, Reid J. Epstein and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: To Battle Wartime Hunger, Gazans Turn to a Humble Leafy Green
articles.snippet: Palestinians have long gathered and cooked khobeza, a spinach-like wild plant that sprouts after rains. Now, it has become a lifeline.
articles.abstract: Palestinians have long gathered and cooked khobeza, a spinach-like wild plant that sprouts after rains. Now, it has become a lifeline.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Israeli military campaign to destroy Hamas pummeled his neighborhood in northern Gaza, reducing buildings to rubble and forcing residents to flee, the Palestinian laborer realized that he was running out of food.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard and Bilal Shbair

articles.headline: Guarding Royal Families for $1,000 a Day: Inside Executive Protection Jobs
articles.snippet: How three women trained to work in jobs protecting prominent families and ultra-high-net-worth individuals.
articles.abstract: How three women trained to work in jobs protecting prominent families and ultra-high-net-worth individuals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Monica Duperon Rodriguez welled up with feelings of awe when she stepped off a charter flight onto the Serengeti in Africa for a job assignment.

articles.headline: Can Minor League Baseball Survive Its Real Estate Problems?
articles.snippet: The fight over a new stadium for the Eugene Emeralds highlights a wider challenge for cheaper alternatives to big-league live sports.
articles.abstract: The fight over a new stadium for the Eugene Emeralds highlights a wider challenge for cheaper alternatives to big-league live sports.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ed Willson has a jar filled with dirt sitting on his desk.

articles.headline: Thirty Years After a Genocide in Rwanda, Painful Memories Run Deep
articles.snippet: The Central African country is marking the anniversary of a monthslong rampage by militiamen that killed some 800,000 people.
articles.abstract: The Central African country is marking the anniversary of a monthslong rampage by militiamen that killed some 800,000 people.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the marauding militiamen arrived at her door on that morning in April 1994, Florence Mukantaganda knew there was nowhere to run.

articles.headline: Israel Withdraws Troops From Southern Gaza as War Hits 6-Month Mark
articles.snippet: With the conflict at an apparent impasse, international mediators were gathering in Cairo with hopes of brokering a temporary cease-fire.
articles.abstract: With the conflict at an apparent impasse, international mediators were gathering in Cairo with hopes of brokering a temporary cease-fire.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Israeli military said Sunday that it had withdrawn a division of ground troops from the southern Gaza Strip, as international mediators gathered with hopes of brokering a temporary cease-fire six months into a war that has now become the longest involving Israel since the 1980s.
articles.byline: By Adam Rasgon, Patrick Kingsley, Ephrat Livni and Matt Stevens

articles.headline: What Chinese Outrage Over ‘3 Body Problem’ Says About China
articles.snippet: The Netflix series showcases one of the country’s most successful works of culture. Instead of demonstrating pride, social media is condemning it.
articles.abstract: The Netflix series showcases one of the country’s most successful works of culture. Instead of demonstrating pride, social media is condemning it.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first five minutes of the Netflix series “3 Body Problem” were hard to watch.

articles.headline: When Home Is Now the Front Line
articles.snippet: As war beat a path through southern and eastern Ukraine, most of the population fled. But other residents have hunkered down, unable — or unwilling — to leave.
articles.abstract: As war beat a path through southern and eastern Ukraine, most of the population fled. But other residents have hunkered down, unable — or unwilling — to leave.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two years after Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, the hourly artillery duels, airstrikes and pitched fighting in the country’s east and south have turned the more than 600-mile front line into a scarred frontier. Parts of it may be uninhabitable for years, if not decades. Villages and towns are destroyed. Fields are mined. Roads are barely recognizable.
articles.byline: By Emile Ducke, Oleksandr Naselenko and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: TSMC Will Receive $6.6 Billion to Bolster U.S. Chip Manufacturing
articles.snippet: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company plans to build an additional factory and upgrade another planned facility in Phoenix with the federal grants.
articles.abstract: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company plans to build an additional factory and upgrade another planned facility in Phoenix with the federal grants.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration will award up to $6.6 billion in grants to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company, the leading maker of the most advanced microchips, in a bid to bring some of the most cutting-edge semiconductor technology to the United States.
articles.byline: By Madeleine Ngo and Don Clark

articles.headline: Biden Announces Student Debt Relief for Millions in Swing-State Pitch
articles.snippet: During an appearance in Wisconsin, President Biden said 10 million borrowers could see debt relief of at least $5,000. The plan could help rally support among young voters.
articles.abstract: During an appearance in Wisconsin, President Biden said 10 million borrowers could see debt relief of at least $5,000. The plan could help rally support among young voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden on Monday announced a large-scale effort to help pay off federal student loans for tens of millions of American borrowers, seeking an election-year boost by returning to a 2020 campaign promise that was blocked by the Supreme Court last year.

articles.headline: Cities in the eclipse’s path are getting an economic ‘shot in the arm.’
articles.snippet: Millions of tourists trying to experience the totality could bolster smaller economies across North America.
articles.abstract: Millions of tourists trying to experience the totality could bolster smaller economies across North America.
articles.lead_paragraph: A vast swath of North America will soon be plunged into darkness. Though momentary, the total solar eclipse on Monday has already proved lucrative.
articles.byline: By Santul Nerkar and J. Edward Moreno

articles.headline: Trump Says Abortion Restrictions Should Be Left to the States
articles.snippet: After months of mixed signals, Donald Trump said that whatever states decide “must be the law of the land,” adding that he was “strongly in favor of exceptions for rape, incest and life of the mother.”
articles.abstract: After months of mixed signals, Donald Trump said that whatever states decide “must be the law of the land,” adding that he was “strongly in favor of exceptions for rape, incest and life of the mother.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said in a video statement on Monday that abortion rights should be left up to the states, remarks that came after months of mixed signals on an issue that he and his advisers have worried could cost him dearly in the election.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Jonathan Swan and Michael Gold

articles.headline: Israel’s Account of Attack on Aid Convoy Raises Wider Legal Questions, Experts Say
articles.snippet: The events that led to the deaths of seven World Central Kitchen workers suggest that there could be problems with the protocols used by the Israeli military, according to legal experts and aid organizations.
articles.abstract: The events that led to the deaths of seven World Central Kitchen workers suggest that there could be problems with the protocols used by the Israeli military, according to legal experts and aid organizations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel’s account of its attack on a World Central Kitchen convoy raises significant legal questions even if the strike was the result of a series of mistakes, experts say.

articles.headline: Dr. Bob, 75, Knows Aging’s Toll. He Wonders if Biden and Trump Do.
articles.snippet: Dr. Bob Ross cares for the aging residents of Ortonville, Minn, even as he wonders whether he, and the presidential candidates, are up to all their tasks.
articles.abstract: Dr. Bob Ross cares for the aging residents of Ortonville, Minn, even as he wonders whether he, and the presidential candidates, are up to all their tasks.
articles.lead_paragraph: He had become the local expert on what he called the “unwanted side effects of old age,” so Dr. Bob Ross, 75, rubbed arthritis cream onto his hands and walked into an exam room to see his seventh elderly patient of the day. He had been a doctor in the remote town of Ortonville, Minn., for nearly five decades, caring for most of its 2,000 residents as he aged alongside them. He delivered their children, performed their high school physicals, tended to their workplace injuries and now specialized in treating the wide-ranging symptoms of what it meant to grow old in America.
articles.byline: By Eli Saslow and Erin Schaff

articles.headline: Google to Tone Down Message Board After Employees Feud Over War in Gaza
articles.snippet: The company is making changes to a popular message board called Memegen that some employees say sounds a lot like censorship.
articles.abstract: The company is making changes to a popular message board called Memegen that some employees say sounds a lot like censorship.
articles.lead_paragraph: For nearly 14 years, an online message board called Memegen has served as a virtual water cooler for Google employees.

articles.headline: Teen Girls Confront an Epidemic of Deepfake Nudes in Schools
articles.snippet: Using artificial intelligence, middle and high school students have fabricated explicit images of female classmates and shared the doctored pictures.
articles.abstract: Using artificial intelligence, middle and high school students have fabricated explicit images of female classmates and shared the doctored pictures.
articles.lead_paragraph: Westfield Public Schools held a regular board meeting in late March at the local high school, a red brick complex in Westfield, N.J., with a scoreboard outside proudly welcoming visitors to the “Home of the Blue Devils” sports teams.
